title: Edinburgh and its neighbourhood, geological and historical :
author: Miller, Hugh
snippet: some years ago, the horse and man of Parliament Square were taken down, and a report went abroad that they were not to be re-erected, we felt as if an important historic document had been destroyed, and that Edinburgh had one point less of interest than before. And the Burns Monument, regarded simply as a fact, should be at least equally sacred. It is a greatly more wonderful fact than the statue of Charles.

title: Sparks from a Locomotive; or Life and Liberty in Europe. By the author of “Belle Brittan's Letters.” [The dedication signed, H. F., i.e. H. Fuller.]
author: F., H.
snippet: As I am not writing a guide-book, I shall not undertake to describe the wild and novel scenery of this most picturesque of cities; nor the quaint antiquities which meet the eye at every turn. After running up to the top of Calton Hill, the view from which makes one hold his breath; and visiting " Nelson's Monument," which has been not inaptly compared to a " Dutch churn," the " Burns Monument," a tasteful granite structure, just now hung with festive wreaths, etc., etc., I returned to the " Waterloo," and ordered a cab with a driver well posted in the localities. I found him a living directory, who knew every spot of historical interest, and who could recite the legends of the place with a fluency and a brogue almost incomprehensible.

title: From Irish castles to French châteaux,
author: Carson, Norma Bright
snippet: As a park this is a pleasant retreat; all that is picturesque in woodland scenery along a riverside is here to be found. Above it, just across the road, and carefully enclosed, the Burns Monument rests on an eminence. It is not a beautiful sculpture, despite its elaborateness; it has not the significance that would make it even approach the adequate; it has none of the humanity, none of the poetic personality, that characterize the bronze figure in the square at Ayr.

title: John and Betty's Scotch history visit,
author: Williamson, Margaret. [from old catalog]
snippet: High above the river bank, with its all too modern tea gardens, crowded on that Saturday with tourists and holiday makers, stands the Burns Monument; soon discovering that the music came from that direction, Mrs. Pitt led the way up the steep path.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: My own land, nearly four thousand miles away, was to make itself felt and remembered, even amid the notaole in Old World art and nature. I was descending the hill, past that spot on the Southern side, between the London Road and Waterloo Place, where the noble pile of the Royal High-School now marks the site once occupied by the Kirk of Fieid (or Church in the Fields) in which Queen Mary's worthless husband, Darnley, was blown up and murdered in February, 1567 ;—past the handsome little Burns Monument, a pillared Grecian temple on base, with winged griffins supporting an hour-glass ;—past the Prison of Edinboro', embattled with more than forty turrets, and notably handsome (to those who only see it from the outside .')—when I saw something fluttering up the flagstaff Jo. the Royal Hotel, down Prince's Street, and recognized, for the first time in weeks, the starry flag which had so lately been raised anew over the last strong-hold of rebellion !
